docs.title: OmniAgent
docs.text:
Your AI representative across communication channels.

OmniAgent is a personal AI assistant that routes messages across multiple communication platforms, processes them via an AI agent, and responds on your behalf.

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• 💬 Multi-Channel Support - Telegram, Discord, Slack, WhatsApp, and more
  • 🤖 AI-Powered Responses - Powered by omnillm (Claude, GPT, Gemini, etc.)
  • 🎤 Voice Notes - Transcribe incoming voice, respond with synthesized speech via OmniVoice
  • 🧩 Skills System - Extensible skills compatible with OpenClaw/ClawHub
  • 🔒 Secure Sandboxing - WASM and Docker isolation for tool execution
  • 🌐 Browser Automation - Built-in browser control via Rod
  • 🔌 WebSocket Gateway - Real-time control plane for device connections
  • 📊 Observability - Integrated tracing via omniobserve

docs.title: Installation
docs.text: go install github.com/plexusone/omniagent/cmd/omniagent@latest

docs.title: WhatsApp + OpenAI
docs.text:
The fastest way to get started:

# Set your OpenAI API key
export OPENAI_API_KEY="sk-..."

# Run with WhatsApp enabled
OMNIAGENT_AGENT_PROVIDER=openai \
OMNIAGENT_AGENT_MODEL=gpt-4o \
WHATSAPP_ENABLED=true \
omniagent gateway run

A QR code will appear in your terminal. Scan it with WhatsApp to connect.

docs.title: Getting Started
docs.text: This guide will help you get OmniAgent up and running quickly.

docs.title: From Source
docs.text: go install github.com/plexusone/omniagent/cmd/omniagent@latest

docs.title: Verify Installation
docs.text: omniagent version

docs.title: Quick Start with WhatsApp
docs.text:
The fastest way to get started is with WhatsApp and OpenAI:

# Set your OpenAI API key
export OPENAI_API_KEY="sk-..."

# Run with WhatsApp enabled
OMNIAGENT_AGENT_PROVIDER=openai \
OMNIAGENT_AGENT_MODEL=gpt-4o \
WHATSAPP_ENABLED=true \
omniagent gateway run

A QR code will appear in your terminal. Scan it with WhatsApp (Settings → Linked Devices → Link a Device) to connect.

docs.title: Configuration File
docs.text:
For more control, create a configuration file:

# omniagent.yaml
gateway:
  address: "127.0.0.1:18789"

agent:
  provider: openai          # or: anthropic, gemini
  model: gpt-4o             # or: claude-sonnet-4-20250514, gemini-2.0-flash
  api_key: ${OPENAI_API_KEY}
  system_prompt: "You are OmniAgent, responding on behalf of the user."

channels:
  whatsapp:
    enabled: true
    db_path: "whatsapp.db"  # Session storage

  telegram:
    enabled: false
    token: ${TELEGRAM_BOT_TOKEN}

  discord:
    enabled: false
    token: ${DISCORD_BOT_TOKEN}

voice:
  enabled: true
  response_mode: auto        # auto, always, never
  stt:
    provider: deepgram
    model: nova-2
  tts:
    provider: deepgram
    model: aura-asteria-en
    voice_id: aura-asteria-en

skills:
  enabled: true
  paths:                     # Additional skill directories
    - ~/.omniagent/skills
  max_injected: 20           # Max skills to inject into prompt

Run with the config file:

omniagent gateway run --config omniagent.yaml

docs.title: Architecture Overview
docs.text: OmniAgent is designed as a modular AI agent framework with clear separation between messaging channels, agent runtime, and tool execution.

docs.title: Gateway
docs.text:
The WebSocket gateway serves as the control plane for OmniAgent:

  • Manages client connections
  • Routes messages to/from channels
  • Provides health check endpoints
  • Handles authentication (planned)
gateway, _ := gateway.New(gateway.Config{
    Address:      "127.0.0.1:18789",
    ReadTimeout:  30 * time.Second,
    WriteTimeout: 30 * time.Second,
})
gateway.Run(ctx)

docs.title: Agent Runtime
docs.text:
The agent processes messages using LLM providers:

agent, _ := agent.New(agent.Config{
    Provider:     "anthropic",
    Model:        "claude-sonnet-4-20250514",
    SystemPrompt: "You are OmniAgent...",
})

response, _ := agent.Process(ctx, message)

docs.title: Channels
docs.text:
Channels connect to external messaging platforms via omnichat:

  • WhatsApp - Via WhatsApp Web protocol
  • Telegram - Via Bot API
  • Discord - Via Bot API

docs.title: Skills System
docs.text:
Skills extend agent capabilities via SKILL.md files:

┌─────────────┐    ┌─────────────┐    ┌─────────────┐
│ Skill       │───▶│ Skill       │───▶│ System      │
│ Discovery   │    │ Loader      │    │ Prompt      │
└─────────────┘    └─────────────┘    └─────────────┘

See Skills System for details.

docs.title: Sandbox
docs.text:
Tools execute in isolated environments:

  • App-Level - Capability-based permissions
  • WASM - Lightweight isolation via wazero
  • Docker - Full container isolation

docs.title: Message Processing
docs.text:
1. Channel receives message
         │
         ▼
2. Gateway routes to agent
         │
         ▼
3. Agent loads skills into prompt
         │
         ▼
4. LLM processes message
         │
         ▼
5. Tools execute in sandbox
         │
         ▼
6. Response sent via channel

docs.title: Voice Processing
docs.text:
1. Voice message received
         │
         ▼
2. STT transcription (omnivoice)
         │
         ▼
3. Agent processes text
         │
         ▼
4. TTS synthesis (omnivoice)
         │
         ▼
5. Voice response sent

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text:
OmniAgent uses a layered configuration system:

  1. Defaults - Built-in sensible defaults
  2. Config File - YAML/JSON configuration
  3. Environment Variables - Override specific values
# omniagent.yaml
gateway:
  address: "127.0.0.1:18789"

agent:
  provider: ${OMNIAGENT_AGENT_PROVIDER:-anthropic}
  model: ${OMNIAGENT_AGENT_MODEL:-claude-sonnet-4-20250514}

docs.title: Skills System Architecture
docs.text: The skills system enables OmniAgent to load and use skills compatible with OpenClaw and ClawHub.

docs.title: Phase 1: Skill Loader (Current)
docs.text:
Parses SKILL.md files and injects content into the LLM system prompt.

Capabilities:

  • Parse YAML frontmatter + Markdown body
  • Discover skills from multiple directories
  • Check binary and environment requirements
  • Inject into system prompt with emoji support

docs.title: Phase 2: Hook Runner (Planned)
docs.text:
Execute TypeScript/shell hooks via Deno runtime.

Capabilities:

  • Run TypeScript hooks with restricted permissions
  • OpenClaw hook API compatibility
  • Shell script execution

docs.title: Phase 3: Tool Sandbox (Current)
docs.text:
Secure execution environment for tools.

Capabilities:

  • WASM runtime via wazero
  • Docker container isolation
  • Capability-based permissions

docs.title: Skill
docs.text:
type Skill struct {
    // From YAML frontmatter
    Name        string
    Description string
    Homepage    string
    Metadata    SkillMeta

    // Parsed from file
    Content     string // Markdown body
    Path        string // Directory path
    HasHooks    bool   // Has hooks/ directory
    HasScripts  bool   // Has scripts/ directory
}

docs.title: SkillMeta
docs.text:
type SkillMeta struct {
    Emoji    string
    Requires *Requires
    Install  []Installer
    Always   bool
}

type Requires struct {
    Bins    []string // Required binaries
    AnyBins []string // At least one required
    Env     []string // Required env vars
}

docs.title: Skill Discovery
docs.text:
Skills are discovered from configured directories:

func DefaultSearchPaths() []string {
    home, _ := os.UserHomeDir()
    return []string{
        filepath.Join(home, ".omniagent", "skills"),
        "skills",
        ".skills",
    }
}

Discovery process:

  1. Scan each directory for subdirectories
  2. Check for SKILL.md file in each subdirectory
  3. Parse and validate the skill
  4. Deduplicate by name (first wins)

docs.title: Requirement Checking
docs.text:
Before loading a skill, requirements are validated:

func (s *Skill) CheckRequirements() []error {
    // Check required binaries
    for _, bin := range req.Bins {
        if _, err := exec.LookPath(bin); err != nil {
            // Missing binary
        }
    }

    // Check anyBins (at least one must exist)
    // Check required env vars
}

Skills with missing requirements are skipped by default.

docs.title: Prompt Injection
docs.text:
Skills are injected into the system prompt:

func InjectIntoPrompt(systemPrompt string, skills []*Skill, cfg InjectConfig) string {
    var sb strings.Builder
    sb.WriteString(systemPrompt)
    sb.WriteString("\n\n# Available Skills\n\n")

    for _, skill := range skills {
        sb.WriteString("## ")
        sb.WriteString(skill.Metadata.Emoji)
        sb.WriteString(" ")
        sb.WriteString(skill.Name)
        sb.WriteString("\n\n")
        sb.WriteString(skill.Content)
        sb.WriteString("\n\n---\n\n")
    }

    return sb.String()
}

docs.title: Sandboxing
docs.text: OmniAgent provides layered security for tool execution through capability-based permissions and runtime isolation.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
Tools can be sandboxed at multiple levels:

  1. App-Level Permissions - Capability-based access control
  2. WASM Isolation - Lightweight sandboxing via wazero
  3. Docker Isolation - Full container isolation

docs.title: Capabilities
docs.text:
Tools request specific capabilities:

Capability Description fs_read Read files from allowed paths fs_write Write files to allowed paths net_http Make HTTP requests to allowed hosts exec_run Execute allowed commands

docs.title: Configuration
docs.text:
config := sandbox.Config{
    Capabilities: []sandbox.Capability{
        sandbox.CapFSRead,
        sandbox.CapNetHTTP,
    },
    AllowedPaths: []string{"/tmp/data", "/home/user/docs"},
    AllowedHosts: []string{"api.example.com"},
    AllowedCommands: []string{"ls", "cat"},
}

docs.title: WASM Sandbox
docs.text: For lightweight isolation, tools can run in a WASM sandbox using wazero.

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• Memory limits
  • Timeout enforcement
  • No network access by default
  • Restricted file system access

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
runtime, err := sandbox.NewRuntime(ctx, sandbox.Config{
    Capabilities:  []sandbox.Capability{sandbox.CapFSRead},
    MemoryLimitMB: 16,
    Timeout:       30 * time.Second,
    AllowedPaths:  []string{"/tmp/data"},
})

result, err := runtime.Run(ctx, wasmModule, args)

docs.title: Host Functions
docs.text:
The WASM sandbox exposes controlled host functions:

Function Capability Required Description fs_read CapFSRead Read file contents fs_write CapFSWrite Write file contents http_fetch CapNetHTTP Make HTTP requests exec_run CapExecRun Execute commands

docs.title: Docker Sandbox
docs.text: For OS-level isolation, tools can run inside Docker containers.

docs.title: Features
docs.text:
• Full process isolation
  • Network restrictions
  • Capability dropping
  • Read-only mounts

docs.title: Usage
docs.text:
sandbox, err := sandbox.NewDockerSandbox(ctx, sandbox.DockerConfig{
    Image:       "alpine:latest",
    NetworkMode: "none",           // No network access
    CapDrop:     []string{"ALL"},  // Drop all capabilities
    Mounts: []sandbox.DockerMount{
        {
            HostPath:      "/tmp/data",
            ContainerPath: "/data",
            ReadOnly:      true,
        },
    },
}, &appConfig)

result, err := sandbox.Run(ctx, "cat", []string{"/data/file.txt"})

docs.title: Network Modes
docs.text: Mode Description none No network access bridge Isolated network with NAT host Full host network access (not recommended)

docs.title: Security Hardening
docs.text:
config := sandbox.DockerConfig{
    Image:       "alpine:latest",
    NetworkMode: "none",
    CapDrop:     []string{"ALL"},
    ReadOnlyRootfs: true,
    NoNewPrivileges: true,
}

docs.title: Principle of Least Privilege
docs.text:
Only grant the minimum capabilities required:

// Bad: Too permissive
config := sandbox.Config{
    Capabilities: []sandbox.Capability{
        sandbox.CapFSRead,
        sandbox.CapFSWrite,
        sandbox.CapNetHTTP,
        sandbox.CapExecRun,
    },
}

// Good: Minimal permissions
config := sandbox.Config{
    Capabilities: []sandbox.Capability{sandbox.CapFSRead},
    AllowedPaths: []string{"/tmp/readonly"},
}

docs.title: Path Restrictions
docs.text:
Always restrict file access to specific directories:

config := sandbox.Config{
    AllowedPaths: []string{
        "/tmp/workspace",
        "/home/user/data",
    },
}

docs.title: Command Allowlists
docs.text:
Only allow specific commands for exec:

config := sandbox.Config{
    AllowedCommands: []string{"ls", "cat", "grep"},
}

docs.title: Timeouts
docs.text:
Always set reasonable timeouts:

config := sandbox.Config{
    Timeout: 30 * time.Second,
}

docs.title: Choosing a Sandbox
docs.text: Use Case Recommended Simple file operations App-level permissions Untrusted code execution WASM sandbox Complex tools with dependencies Docker sandbox Maximum isolation Docker with none network

docs.title: Skills Development
docs.text: OmniAgent supports skills compatible with the OpenClaw SKILL.md format. Skills extend the agent's capabilities by injecting domain-specific instructions into the system prompt.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: Skills are Markdown files with YAML frontmatter that teach your agent how to perform specific tasks. They're injected into the LLM's system prompt at runtime.

docs.title: Skill Format
docs.text:
Skills are defined in SKILL.md files:

---
name: weather
description: Get weather forecasts
metadata:
  emoji: "🌤️"
  requires:
    bins: ["curl"]
  install:
    - name: curl
      brew: curl
      apt: curl
---

# Weather Skill

You can check the weather using the `curl` command:

## Get Current Weather

```bash
curl "wttr.in/London?format=3"

docs.title: Get Detailed Forecast
docs.text:
curl "wttr.in/London"

## Skill Discovery

Skills are discovered from:

1. Built-in skills directory
2. `~/.omniagent/skills/`
3. Custom paths via `skills.paths` config

```yaml
skills:
  enabled: true
  paths:
    - ~/.omniagent/skills
    - /opt/shared-skills
  max_injected: 20

docs.title: List Skills
docs.text:
omniagent skills list

Output: 

✓ 🎵 sonoscli - Control Sonos speakers via CLI
✓ 🐙 github - GitHub CLI operations
✗ ☀️ weather - Weather forecasts (missing: weather binary)

docs.title: Show Skill Details
docs.text: omniagent skills info sonoscli

docs.title: Check Requirements
docs.text: omniagent skills check

docs.title: Requirements
docs.text: Skills can declare requirements that must be met:

docs.title: Binary Requirements
docs.text:
metadata:
  requires:
    bins: ["gh", "jq"]  # All required
    anyBins: ["curl", "wget"]  # At least one required

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text:
metadata:
  requires:
    env: ["GITHUB_TOKEN", "OPENAI_API_KEY"]

docs.title: Install Hints
docs.text:
metadata:
  install:
    - name: gh
      brew: gh
      apt: gh
    - name: jq
      brew: jq
      apt: jq

docs.title: 1. Create Directory
docs.text: mkdir -p ~/.omniagent/skills/myskill

docs.title: 2. Create SKILL.md
docs.text:
---
name: myskill
description: My custom skill
metadata:
  emoji: "🔧"
---

# My Skill

Instructions for the AI agent on how to use this skill...

## Available Commands

- `mytool list` - List all items
- `mytool add <name>` - Add a new item

docs.title: 3. Verify
docs.text:
omniagent skills list
omniagent skills info myskill

docs.title: Keep Instructions Clear
docs.text: Write instructions as if explaining to a human who knows nothing about your tool.

docs.title: Include Examples
docs.text: Show concrete examples of commands and expected output.

docs.title: Declare Requirements
docs.text: Always declare binary and environment requirements so users know what's needed.

docs.title: Use Emojis Sparingly
docs.text: One emoji in the metadata helps identify skills visually.

docs.title: ClawHub Compatibility
docs.text:
OmniAgent is compatible with skills from ClawHub. Install skills using:

# Coming soon
bunx clawhub install sonoscli

Or manually clone to your skills directory:

git clone https://github.com/user/skill ~/.omniagent/skills/skill

docs.title: Voice Integration
docs.text: OmniAgent supports voice notes via OmniVoice, providing speech-to-text (STT) and text-to-speech (TTS) capabilities.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text:
When voice processing is enabled:

  1. Incoming voice messages are transcribed to text
  2. The text is processed by the AI agent
  3. Responses can be synthesized back to speech

docs.title: Supported Providers
docs.text: Provider STT TTS Notes Deepgram ✅ ✅ Nova-2 for STT, Aura voices for TTS OpenAI ✅ ✅ Whisper for STT, TTS-1 for TTS ElevenLabs ❌ ✅ High-quality voice synthesis

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text: Variable Description DEEPGRAM_API_KEY Deepgram API key OPENAI_API_KEY OpenAI API key (for Whisper/TTS) ELEVENLABS_API_KEY ElevenLabs API key OMNIAGENT_VOICE_ENABLED Enable voice processing OMNIAGENT_VOICE_RESPONSE_MODE Response mode: auto, always, never

docs.title: Config File
docs.text:
voice:
  enabled: true
  response_mode: auto

  stt:
    provider: deepgram
    model: nova-2

  tts:
    provider: deepgram
    model: aura-asteria-en
    voice_id: aura-asteria-en

docs.title: Response Modes
docs.text: Mode Behavior auto Reply with voice only to voice messages always Always reply with voice never Never reply with voice (text only)

docs.title: Deepgram
docs.text:
1. Sign up at deepgram.com
  2. Create an API key
  3. Set DEEPGRAM_API_KEY environment variable
voice:
  stt:
    provider: deepgram
    model: nova-2
  tts:
    provider: deepgram
    model: aura-asteria-en

docs.title: OpenAI
docs.text:
Uses your existing OpenAI API key:

voice:
  stt:
    provider: openai
    model: whisper-1
  tts:
    provider: openai
    model: tts-1
    voice_id: alloy

docs.title: ElevenLabs (TTS only)
docs.text:
1. Sign up at elevenlabs.io
  2. Create an API key
  3. Set ELEVENLABS_API_KEY environment variable
voice:
  tts:
    provider: elevenlabs
    voice_id: your-voice-id

docs.title: Architecture
docs.text:
OmniVoice uses a provider registry pattern:

import (
    "github.com/plexusone/omnivoice"
    _ "github.com/plexusone/omnivoice/providers/all" // Register all providers
)

// Get providers by name
stt, _ := omnivoice.GetSTTProvider("deepgram", omnivoice.WithAPIKey(key))
tts, _ := omnivoice.GetTTSProvider("elevenlabs", omnivoice.WithAPIKey(key))

docs.title: Voice Not Working
docs.text:
1. Verify API keys are set correctly
  2. Check that voice is enabled in config
  3. Ensure the provider supports your chosen model

docs.title: Poor Transcription Quality
docs.text:
• Use Deepgram Nova-2 or OpenAI Whisper for best results
  • Ensure audio quality is reasonable
  • Check language settings match the spoken language

docs.title: TTS Sounds Robotic
docs.text:
• Try different voice IDs
  • ElevenLabs offers the most natural-sounding voices
  • Adjust model settings if available

docs.title: WhatsApp Setup
docs.text: This guide covers setting up OmniAgent with WhatsApp.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: OmniAgent connects to WhatsApp using the WhatsApp Web protocol via whatsmeow. This allows your agent to send and receive messages without requiring WhatsApp Business API access.

docs.title: Quick Start
docs.text:
export OPENAI_API_KEY="sk-..."
WHATSAPP_ENABLED=true omniagent gateway run

docs.title: Environment Variables
docs.text: Variable Description Default WHATSAPP_ENABLED Enable WhatsApp channel false WHATSAPP_DB_PATH Session database path whatsapp.db

docs.title: Config File
docs.text:
channels:
  whatsapp:
    enabled: true
    db_path: "whatsapp.db"

docs.title: Linking Your Phone
docs.text:
When you start the gateway with WhatsApp enabled:

  1. A QR code appears in your terminal
  2. Open WhatsApp on your phone
  3. Go to Settings → Linked Devices → Link a Device
  4. Scan the QR code

Session Persistence

The session is stored in whatsapp.db. Delete this file to unlink and start fresh.

docs.title: How It Works
docs.text:
┌─────────────┐    ┌─────────────┐    ┌─────────────┐
│  WhatsApp   │───▶│  OmniAgent  │───▶│    LLM      │
│   (Phone)   │◀───│   Gateway   │◀───│  Provider   │
└─────────────┘    └─────────────┘    └─────────────┘
  1. Messages arrive via WhatsApp Web protocol
  2. OmniAgent processes them through the AI agent
  3. Responses are sent back to the conversation

docs.title: Voice Notes
docs.text:
OmniAgent supports voice notes when voice processing is enabled:

channels:
  whatsapp:
    enabled: true

voice:
  enabled: true
  response_mode: auto  # Reply with voice to voice messages
  stt:
    provider: deepgram
  tts:
    provider: deepgram

See Voice Integration for details.

docs.title: QR Code Not Appearing
docs.text: Ensure no other WhatsApp Web sessions are interfering. Delete whatsapp.db and restart.

docs.title: Connection Drops
docs.text: The WhatsApp Web connection may drop occasionally. OmniAgent will automatically reconnect when possible.

docs.title: Rate Limiting
docs.text: WhatsApp may rate-limit accounts sending too many messages. Use reasonable response times and avoid spamming.

docs.title: Security Considerations
docs.text:
• The whatsapp.db file contains your session credentials - keep it secure
  • Messages are processed through your configured LLM provider
  • Consider the privacy implications of routing messages through AI

docs.title: Minimal Setup (WhatsApp + OpenAI)
docs.text:
export OPENAI_API_KEY="sk-..."
export WHATSAPP_ENABLED=true

omniagent gateway run

docs.title: Full Setup
docs.text:
# LLM Provider
export ANTHROPIC_API_KEY="sk-ant-..."
export OMNIAGENT_AGENT_PROVIDER=anthropic
export OMNIAGENT_AGENT_MODEL=claude-sonnet-4-20250514

# WhatsApp
export WHATSAPP_ENABLED=true
export WHATSAPP_DB_PATH=~/.omniagent/whatsapp.db

# Voice
export DEEPGRAM_API_KEY="..."
export OMNIAGENT_VOICE_ENABLED=true
export OMNIAGENT_VOICE_RESPONSE_MODE=auto

# Gateway
export OMNIAGENT_GATEWAY_ADDRESS=0.0.0.0:18789

omniagent gateway run

docs.title: Using .envrc (direnv)
docs.text:
Create a .envrc file in your project directory:

# .envrc
export OPENAI_API_KEY="sk-..."
export ANTHROPIC_API_KEY="sk-ant-..."
export DEEPGRAM_API_KEY="..."

export OMNIAGENT_AGENT_PROVIDER=anthropic
export WHATSAPP_ENABLED=true
export OMNIAGENT_VOICE_ENABLED=true

Then allow it:

direnv allow
omniagent gateway run

docs.title: Precedence
docs.text:
Configuration values are resolved in this order (highest to lowest):

  1. Environment variables
  2. Config file values
  3. Built-in defaults

Example:

# omniagent.yaml
agent:
  provider: openai

# Environment overrides config file
export OMNIAGENT_AGENT_PROVIDER=anthropic
omniagent gateway run  # Uses anthropic

docs.title: Release Notes: v0.3.0
docs.text: Release Date: 2026-02-22

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: OmniAgent v0.3.0 introduces a powerful skill system compatible with OpenClaw/ClawHub and layered sandboxing for secure tool execution. This release significantly expands the agent's extensibility while maintaining security through WASM and Docker isolation.

docs.title: Highlights
docs.text:
• Skill System - Load and use skills from the OpenClaw/ClawHub ecosystem
  • WASM Sandboxing - Lightweight isolation using wazero runtime
  • Docker Sandboxing - OS-level container isolation for CLI tools

docs.title: Skill System
docs.text:
OmniAgent now supports skills compatible with the OpenClaw SKILL.md format, enabling you to extend your agent with domain-specific capabilities.

Key capabilities:

  • Parse SKILL.md files with YAML frontmatter and metadata
  • Discover skills from multiple directories with deduplication
  • Check requirements (binaries, environment variables) with install hints
  • Inject skill instructions into the system prompt

CLI commands:

omniagent skills list      # List all discovered skills
omniagent skills info NAME # Show skill details and requirements
omniagent skills check     # Validate all skill requirements

Configuration:

skills:
  enabled: true
  paths:
    - ~/.omniagent/skills
    - /opt/skills
  disabled:
    - experimental-skill
  max_injected: 20

docs.title: WASM Sandbox
docs.text:
A lightweight sandbox using wazero provides capability-based isolation for tool execution.

Capabilities:

Capability Description fs_read Read files from allowed paths fs_write Write files to allowed paths net_http Make HTTP requests to allowed hosts exec_run Execute allowed commands

Security features:

  • Memory limits (default 16MB, max 4GB)
  • Timeout enforcement via context
  • Path validation with symlink resolution
  • Command allowlist enforcement

docs.title: Docker Sandbox
docs.text:
For stronger OS-level isolation, tools can run inside Docker containers with security hardening.

Default security settings:

  • NetworkMode: none - No network access
  • CapDrop: ALL - Drop all Linux capabilities
  • ReadonlyRootfs: true - Read-only root filesystem
  • SecurityOpt: no-new-privileges - Prevent privilege escalation
  • Memory and CPU limits

Volume mounts allow controlled filesystem access:

Mounts: []sandbox.DockerMount{
    {HostPath: "/data/input", ContainerPath: "/input", ReadOnly: true},
    {HostPath: "/data/output", ContainerPath: "/output", ReadOnly: false},
}

docs.title: Bug Fixes
docs.text: • Config tests now clear environment variables to prevent interference from user's shell environment

docs.title: Highlights

• Organization Migration - Module path changed from github.com/agentplexus/omniagent to github.com/plexusone/omniagent
  • Batteries-Included OmniVoice - Simplified voice integration with automatic provider registration

docs.title: Module Path Change
docs.text:
The module path has changed:

// Old
import "github.com/agentplexus/omniagent"

// New
import "github.com/plexusone/omniagent"

Update your go.mod:

go get github.com/plexusone/omniagent@v0.4.0

docs.title: Voice Processor Refactoring
docs.text:
The voice processor now uses OmniVoice's registry pattern:

// Old approach (direct provider imports)
import "github.com/plexusone/omnivoice-deepgram"
provider := deepgram.New(apiKey)

// New approach (registry pattern)
import (
    "github.com/plexusone/omnivoice"
    _ "github.com/plexusone/omnivoice/providers/all"
)
provider, _ := omnivoice.GetSTTProvider("deepgram", omnivoice.WithAPIKey(apiKey))

Benefits:

  • Single import for all providers
  • Runtime provider selection
  • Consistent configuration interface
